elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) incorporating lanthanide nodes and tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) linkers offer a viable approach for combining redox activity and magnetism in one material. Four rare-earth lanthanide ions (RE = Tb, Dy, Ho, and Er) were found to form isostructural MOFs consisting of metal chains bridged by redox-active tetrathiafulvalene-tetrabenzoate (TTFTB4–) whereby the carboxylate moieties act in both anti-anti and syn-syn coordination modes. These materials display tunable redox-active properties and slow magnetic relaxation phenomenon (Er and Dy). While the as-synthesized crystals contain the neutral diamagnetic TTF moiety, using either a solid-solution electrochemical method or iodine oxidation transforms part of the latter to the paramagnetic TTF•+ radical in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal manner without altering the internal structure of the building chains and the frameworks. This is accompanied by inclusion of I3 – replacing some of the solvents, as well as changes in the central C–C bond length of TTFTB, a strong EPR response at g ∼ 2, and an enhancement of the reflectance at low energies originating from absorption by the radical.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) incorporating lanthanide nodes and tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) linkers offer a viable approach for combining redox activity and magnetism in one material. Four rare-earth lanthanide ions (RE = Tb, Dy, Ho, and Er) were found to form isostructural MOFs consisting of metal chains bridged by redox-active tetrathiafulvalene-tetrabenzoate (TTFTB4-) whereby the carboxylate moieties act in both anti-anti and syn-syn coordination modes. These materials display tunable redox-active properties and slow magnetic relaxation phenomenon (Er and Dy). While the as-synthesized crystals contain the neutral diamagnetic TTF moiety, using either a solid-solution electrochemical method or iodine oxidation transforms part of the latter to the paramagnetic TTF⋅+ radical in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal manner without altering the internal structure of the building chains and the frameworks. This is accompanied by inclusion of I3 - replacing some of the solvents, as well as changes in the central C-C bond length of TTFTB, a strong EPR response at g ~ 2, and an enhancement of the reflectance at low energies originating from absorption by the radical.

elements.content: A series of three-dimensional metal−organic frameworks combining both tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) derivatives and lanthanide ions (Tb, Dy, Ho, and Er) are synthesized. These MOF show tunable redox-active properties, but slow magnetic relaxation was observed only for the Er and Dy complexes. The single crystal structure of oxidized MOF was obtained by original chemical oxidation through the single crystal-to-single crystal transformation.
elements.clean_text: A series of three-dimensional metal-organic frameworks combining both tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) derivatives and lanthanide ions (Tb, Dy, Ho, and Er) are synthesized. These MOF show tunable redox-active properties, but slow magnetic relaxation was observed only for the Er and Dy complexes. The single crystal structure of oxidized MOF was obtained by original chemical oxidation through the single crystal-to-single crystal transformation.

elements.content: Around 30 years ago, organic conducting salts derived from cationic tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) derivatives with a range of paramagnetic inorganic anions were developed for studying the influence of the magnetic moments on the conductivity. The field exploded when superconductivity for cationic layers of bis­(ethylenedithio)-tetrathiafulvalene (BEDT-TTF) interleaved with polymeric magnetic sheets of iron­(III) oxalate was discovered. This was followed by some key observations including (a) field-induced superconductivity from a conducting antiferromagnetic ground state, (b) an organic conductor with a ferromagnetic sheet of Mn­(II)–Cr­(III) oxalate, (c) electronic and proton conductivities, and (d) a canted antiferromagnet invoking both spins in chains of Fe­(III)-oxalate and TTF•+. Many more examples have since been reported, and several other ground states have been proposed. The advent of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) in the 1990s opened a new direction which is now using functionalized TTFs as connecting ligands to develop conducting solids. Also, the electron-rich TTF can serve as a functional guest to induce the charge transfer and adjust the bandgap of semiconductor MOFs in which the reported bandgaps are always below 4.5 eV. Critically, the electroactivity of the TTF moiety has been used as an “ON–OFF” switch to modulate the magnetic and luminescent properties in a range of materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Around 30 years ago, organic conducting salts derived from cationic tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) derivatives with a range of paramagnetic inorganic anions were developed for studying the influence of the magnetic moments on the conductivity. The field exploded when superconductivity for cationic layers of bis(ethylenedithio)-tetrathiafulvalene (BEDT-TTF) interleaved with polymeric magnetic sheets of iron(III) oxalate was discovered. This was followed by some key observations including (a) field-induced superconductivity from a conducting antiferromagnetic ground state, (b) an organic conductor with a ferromagnetic sheet of Mn(II)-Cr(III) oxalate, (c) electronic and proton conductivities, and (d) a canted antiferromagnet invoking both spins in chains of Fe(III)-oxalate and TTF⋅+. Many more examples have since been reported, and several other ground states have been proposed. The advent of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) in the 1990s opened a new direction which is now using functionalized TTFs as connecting ligands to develop conducting solids. Also, the electron-rich TTF can serve as a functional guest to induce the charge transfer and adjust the bandgap of semiconductor MOFs in which the reported bandgaps are always below 4.5 eV. Critically, the electroactivity of the TTF moiety has been used as an "ON-OFF" switch to modulate the magnetic and luminescent properties in a range of materials.

elements.content: The two prominent varieties of functionalized TTF that have been focused upon are those with pyridine and carboxylate groups, with most of the reported networks incorporating transition metals. In view of the multifunctional nature of rare-earth (RE) metals, including their high coordination numbers from chemical and structural points of view, along with their luminescence and magnetic properties (single-molecule magnet (SMM), single-ion magnet (SIM), magnetic cooling) from the physics perspective, we have synthesized and studied a new series of framework materials using trivalent magnetic terbium {[Xe]­f8, L = 3, S = 6/2}, dysprosium {[Xe]­f9, L = 5, S = 5/2}, holmium {[Xe]­f10, L = 6, S = 2}, and erbium {[Xe]­f11, L = 6, S = 3/2}. We anticipated that the combination of TTF and RE metals would lead to a new class of multifunctional frameworks exhibiting redox activity, electrical conductivity and single-molecule magnetism. In addition, the redox activity of the TTF core, a sulfur-rich conjugated molecule with two reversible and easily accessible oxidation processes to its radical cation (TTF•+) and dication (TTF2+) states, offers a strategy to alter the properties via oxidation without changing the structure. Thus, these attributes deliver a good platform to study structure–property relationships between different oxidation states of TTF. The rational construction of MOF using redox-active tetra­(4-pyridyl)-tetrathiafulvalene and Fe­(II) centers led to two materials which have been reported to exhibit thermal and photoinduced spin-crossover. In addition, the I2 oxidized form exhibits ca. 103 enhancement of the electrical conductivity, modification of the spin crossover (SCO) behavior, and switching off of the light-induced excited state spin trapping (LIEEST) phenomenon. These results complement those of Pointillart’s group related to TTF-Ln magnets of low dimensionalities. Despite major efforts by the scientific community, high electrical conductivity has rarely been observed in TTF-Ln systems. Thus, the challenge to combine redox activity, electrical conductivity and magnetism in a single material remains active.

In addition, the redox activity of the TTF core, a sulfur-rich conjugated molecule with two reversible and easily accessible oxidation processes to its radical cation (TTF⋅+) and dication (TTF2+) states, offers a strategy to alter the properties via oxidation without changing the structure. Thus, these attributes deliver a good platform to study structure-property relationships between different oxidation states of TTF. In addition, the I2 oxidized form exhibits ca. 103 enhancement of the electrical conductivity, modification of the spin crossover (SCO) behavior, and switching off of the light-induced excited state spin trapping (LIEEST) phenomenon. elements.content: The present work reports a new type of MOF generated from tetrathiafulvalene-tetrabenzoate (TTFTB4–) and four different rare-earth (RE) ions derived from RECl3·6H2O (RE = Tb (1-Tb), Dy (1-Dy), Ho (1-Ho) ,and Er (1-Er)) using solvothermal methods, and their postsynthetically modified forms (2-Tb, 2-Dy, 2-Ho, and 2-Er) using solid-solution reactions with crystals suspended in a cyclohexane solution of iodine producing the partially oxidized TTF•+. The framework consists of chains of RE metals where the carboxylate group of TTFTB coordinates in three different bridging modes: RE–(anti-anti COO)–RE, two-blade paddle-wheel RE–(syn-syn COO)2–RE, and four-blade paddle-wheel RE–(syn-syn COO)4–RE. All the as-synthesized and postsynthetically modified MOFs have been subjected to structural characterization and their magnetic, electrical and optical properties are studied. X-ray diffraction confirmed a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation during the solid-solution reaction with the inclusion of I3 – as the charge compensating ion and a characteristic EPR signal for the generated TTF•+. The Dy and Er compounds exhibit weak ferromagnetic interactions and/or dipolar–dipolar interactions and slow magnetic relaxation associated with the radical, in contrast to Tb and Ho analogues.
elements.clean_text: The present work reports a new type of MOF generated from tetrathiafulvalene-tetrabenzoate (TTFTB4-) and four different rare-earth (RE) ions derived from RECl3⋅6H2O (RE = Tb (1-Tb), Dy (1-Dy), Ho (1-Ho) ,and Er (1-Er)) using solvothermal methods, and their postsynthetically modified forms (2-Tb, 2-Dy, 2-Ho, and 2-Er) using solid-solution reactions with crystals suspended in a cyclohexane solution of iodine producing the partially oxidized TTF⋅+. The framework consists of chains of RE metals where the carboxylate group of TTFTB coordinates in three different bridging modes: RE-(anti-anti COO)-RE, two-blade paddle-wheel RE-(syn-syn COO)2-RE, and four-blade paddle-wheel RE-(syn-syn COO)4-RE. All the as-synthesized and postsynthetically modified MOFs have been subjected to structural characterization and their magnetic, electrical and optical properties are studied. X-ray diffraction confirmed a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation during the solid-solution reaction with the inclusion of I3 - as the charge compensating ion and a characteristic EPR signal for the generated TTF⋅+. The Dy and Er compounds exhibit weak ferromagnetic interactions and/or dipolar-dipolar interactions and slow magnetic relaxation associated with the radical, in contrast to Tb and Ho analogues.

Experimental Section

The methods used for elemental analyses, thermogravimetric analysis, infrared spectroscopy, powder and single crystal X-ray diffraction data collection, as well as the structural analyses, magnetic, optical, and electrical property determinations are detailed in the Supporting Information.

elements.content:
H4TTFTB () was prepared according to the reported method.

Syntheses of [RE<sub>2</sub>(TTFTB)<sub>1.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·3DMF·13H<sub>2</sub>O

A common method of synthesis was employed for these four compounds. It follows the dissolution of H4TTFTB (0.014 g, 0.020 mmol) in DMF (1 mL) before addition of a solution of RECl3·6H2O (0.010 g, ∼0.027 mmol) in DMF (1 mL) and H2O (0.5 mL), followed by the addition of CF3COOH (0.1 mL) and chlorobenzene (1 mL). The mixture was heated to 60 °C for 72 h, then allowed to cool to room temperature. The crystalline products were filtered and washed with DMF and CH3COCH3 three times.

H4TTFTB () was prepared according to the reported method. 

Syntheses of [RE2(TTFTB)1.5(H2O)3]⋅3DMF⋅13H2O

A common method of synthesis was employed for these four compounds. It follows the dissolution of H4TTFTB (0.014 g, 0.020 mmol) in DMF (1 mL) before addition of a solution of RECl3⋅6H2O (0.010 g, ~0.027 mmol) in DMF (1 mL) and H2O (0.5 mL), followed by the addition of CF3COOH (0.1 mL) and chlorobenzene (1 mL). The mixture was heated to 60 °C for 72 h, then allowed to cool to room temperature. The crystalline products were filtered and washed with DMF and CH3COCH3 three times.

Synthesis of [RE2(TTFTB)1.5(H2O)3](I3)⋅2(C6H12) (2-RE)

A common method was used involving suspending crystals of 1-RE in a cyclohexane solution of iodine (0.1 M) at room temperature. The color of the crystals gradually deepens and after 2 days they were separated and washed with cyclohexane to remove excess and surface iodine. The amount of iodine incorporated was determined by single crystal XRD and confirmed by thermogravimetric (TGA) (Figure S12) and elemental analyses (EA).

Analyses of the diffraction data for 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er () revealed that they are isostructural three-dimensional MOFs crystallizing in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit (Figure S1) contains two Er atoms, one and a half TTFTB, three coordinated H2O and one free N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). One of the TTFTB4– ligands is coordinated to six Er atoms through the four carboxylate groups in which two are ligated in a chelating bidentate mode and the other in a monodentate mode (Figure S2). Another TTFTB4– is coordinated to eight Er atoms with its eight oxygen atoms from four carboxylates (Figure S2). The Er1 atom is eight-coordinate involving one water and five carboxylate groups from five TTFTB, where three are in chelating bidentate modes and the other two are in a monodentate mode (a). The Er2 atom is seven-coordinate involving two water and five carboxylate groups from five TTFTB where all are in monodentate modes (b). The Er1 and Er2 atoms are linked by the TTFTB to form the one-dimensional structure (d, S3). The chain consists of two different alternating Er pairs bridged by an anti–anti carboxylate (Er···Er = 5.40 Å). One of the pairs has two bridging syn–syn carboxylates (two-blade paddle-wheel; Er···Er = 4.53 Å), and the other has four bridging syn–syn carboxylates (four-blade paddle-wheel; Er···Er = 4.11 Å). Each one-dimensional chain is linked by the polytopic TTFTB4– ligand generating the three-dimensional framework (c, S4, and S5). The Er–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.231–2.519 Å which are comparable to those reported for Er compounds (Table S1). The channels along three crystallographic axes intersect each other to form a 3D rabbit hole network (Figure S4). Along the c-axis, the channel opening is 4.8 Å (Figure S5). In the [110] direction, there are two rhombus channels, 11.7 × 7.3 Å2 and 11.3 × 9.0 Å2 (d). The SQUEEZE calculations in PLATON give a total solvent-accessible volume of 1927.1 Å3 per unit cell, equivalent to 47.9% of the total crystal volume (e). The volume differs slightly for the different metals, for 1-Tb, 1-Dy, and 1-Ho they are 1966.0 (47.8%), 2011.1 (48.1%), and 1941.7 Å3 (47.7%) per unit cell, respectively. These calculations indicate reasonable porosity for 1-RE.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures

Analyses of the diffraction data for 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er () revealed that they are isostructural three-dimensional MOFs crystallizing in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit (Figure S1) contains two Er atoms, one and a half TTFTB, three coordinated H2O and one free N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). One of the TTFTB4- ligands is coordinated to six Er atoms through the four carboxylate groups in which two are ligated in a chelating bidentate mode and the other in a monodentate mode (Figure S2). Another TTFTB4- is coordinated to eight Er atoms with its eight oxygen atoms from four carboxylates (Figure S2). The Er1 atom is eight-coordinate involving one water and five carboxylate groups from five TTFTB, where three are in chelating bidentate modes and the other two are in a monodentate mode (a). The Er2 atom is seven-coordinate involving two water and five carboxylate groups from five TTFTB where all are in monodentate modes (b). The Er1 and Er2 atoms are linked by the TTFTB to form the one-dimensional structure (d, S3). The chain consists of two different alternating Er pairs bridged by an anti-anti carboxylate (Er⋅⋅⋅Er = 5.40 Å). One of the pairs has two bridging syn-syn carboxylates (two-blade paddle-wheel; Er⋅⋅⋅Er = 4.53 Å), and the other has four bridging syn-syn carboxylates (four-blade paddle-wheel; Er⋅⋅⋅Er = 4.11 Å). Each one-dimensional chain is linked by the polytopic TTFTB4- ligand generating the three-dimensional framework (c, S4, and S5). The Er-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.231-2.519 Å which are comparable to those reported for Er compounds (Table S1). The channels along three crystallographic axes intersect each other to form a 3D rabbit hole network (Figure S4). Along the c-axis, the channel opening is 4.8 Å (Figure S5). In the [110] direction, there are two rhombus channels, 11.7 × 7.3 Å2 and 11.3 × 9.0 Å2 (d). The SQUEEZE calculations in PLATON give a total solvent-accessible volume of 1927.1 Å3 per unit cell, equivalent to 47.9% of the total crystal volume (e). The volume differs slightly for the different metals, for 1-Tb, 1-Dy, and 1-Ho they are 1966.0 (47.8%), 2011.1 (48.1%), and 1941.7 Å3 (47.7%) per unit cell, respectively. These calculations indicate reasonable porosity for 1-RE.

elements.content: The absence of any other phases from 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er was confirmed by PXRD measurements in which the diffraction peak positions were in agreement with those calculated from single-crystal X-ray data using the Mercury program (a). Additionally, the PXRD pattern for 1-Er after soaking the material in common organic solvents was retained suggesting good stability, except in water which shows less stability (Figure S6). Furthermore, to study the air and solution stability, the thermal stability was also investigated. The PXRD pattern of 1-Er was unaltered at temperatures up to 400 °C in air (b). More generally, the TGA data for 1-RE showed that the frameworks have good thermal stability up to 500 °C (Figure S7).

Additionally, the PXRD pattern for 1-Er after soaking the material in common organic solvents was retained suggesting good stability, except in water which shows less stability (Figure S6). Furthermore, to study the air and solution stability, the thermal stability was also investigated. The PXRD pattern of 1-Er was unaltered at temperatures up to 400 °C in air (b). More generally, the TGA data for 1-RE showed that the frameworks have good thermal stability up to 500 °C (Figure S7).

elements.content: Reaction with I2 is a commonly employed method to chemically generate oxidized forms of TTF in framework materials. Thus, in view of the chemical and thermal stability of our frameworks, chemical oxidation of 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er was attempted. The crystals immersed in a cyclohexane solution of I2 darken over the 2 days of the reaction while the purple I2 solution was decolorized. Initial attempts to solve the structures using laboratory diffraction data were unsuccessful. However, an acceptable solution of the structure was obtained for 2-Tb ( and S8–10, ) using a synchrotron radiation source but not without some anomalies due to absorption and disorder. Interestingly, the TTF moieties in the framework were partially oxidized to their radical cationic state TTF•+. Three changes accompany the oxidation: (a) The unit cell dimensions are different, but it retains the space group. (b) The central C···C distance of the oxidized TTFTB increased to 1.39 Å which is typical of single bonds in TTF•+, while the other increased to 1.36 Å for partially oxidized TTF (Table S2). (c) I3 – is included in the channels. The single crystal diffraction results were confirmed by TGA analyses of all the 2-RE showing a mass loss attributed to I3 – before 350 °C (Figure S11). Also, the absence of any other phases from 2-Tb, 2-Dy, 2-Ho, and 2-Er was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S12).

The crystals immersed in a cyclohexane solution of I2 darken over the 2 days of the reaction while the purple I2 solution was decolorized. Initial attempts to solve the structures using laboratory diffraction data were unsuccessful. However, an acceptable solution of the structure was obtained for 2-Tb ( and S8-10, ) using a synchrotron radiation source but not without some anomalies due to absorption and disorder. Interestingly, the TTF moieties in the framework were partially oxidized to their radical cationic state TTF⋅+. Three changes accompany the oxidation: (a) The unit cell dimensions are different, but it retains the space group. (b) The central C⋅⋅⋅C distance of the oxidized TTFTB increased to 1.39 Å which is typical of single bonds in TTF⋅+, while the other increased to 1.36 Å for partially oxidized TTF (Table S2). (c) I3 - is included in the channels. The single crystal diffraction results were confirmed by TGA analyses of all the 2-RE showing a mass loss attributed to I3 - before 350 °C (Figure S11). Also, the absence of any other phases from 2-Tb, 2-Dy, 2-Ho, and 2-Er was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S12).

elements.content: Solid-state direct current (dc) cyclic voltammetry (CV) studies on 1-Er were conducted in 0.1 M LiBF4 in CH3CN (a). Upon scanning anodically, two quasi-reversible one-electron processes at 0.22 and 0.53 V (vs Fc/Fc+) were observed. These processes are attributed to the TTF/TTF•+ and TTF•+/TTF2+ redox couples, respectively. In contrast to the CV of the free TTFTB ligand, the two one-electron processes observed for 1-Er are shifted anodically by ca. 0.2 V which is attributed to both the coordination to erbium ions and the deprotonated nature of the ligand. The current associated with the two redox processes decreases over multiple scans which is consistent with their quasi-reversible nature. CV studies for the 1-Tb, 1-Dy, and 1-Ho analogues in 0.1 M LiBF4/CH3CN showed similar results (Figure S13). The values of the TTF/TTF•+ and TTF•+/TTF2+ redox couples for 1-Tb, 1-Dy, and 1-Ho are 0.16 and 0.46 V; 0.16 and 0.45 V; and 0.11 and 0.41 V, respectively. Additionally, faster sweep rates resulted in broad features as a result of slow diffusion kinetics through the framework structure (b and S14). Finally, in all compounds, the postexperiment CVs showed no sign of dissolution or degradation of the frameworks upon electrochemical modulation (Figure S15).
elements.clean_text:
Cyclic Voltammetry

Solid-state direct current (dc) cyclic voltammetry (CV) studies on 1-Er were conducted in 0.1 M LiBF4 in CH3CN (a). Upon scanning anodically, two quasi-reversible one-electron processes at 0.22 and 0.53 V (vs Fc/Fc+) were observed. These processes are attributed to the TTF/TTF⋅+ and TTF⋅+/TTF2+ redox couples, respectively. In contrast to the CV of the free TTFTB ligand, the two one-electron processes observed for 1-Er are shifted anodically by ca. 0.2 V which is attributed to both the coordination to erbium ions and the deprotonated nature of the ligand. The current associated with the two redox processes decreases over multiple scans which is consistent with their quasi-reversible nature. CV studies for the 1-Tb, 1-Dy, and 1-Ho analogues in 0.1 M LiBF4/CH3CN showed similar results (Figure S13). The values of the TTF/TTF⋅+ and TTF⋅+/TTF2+ redox couples for 1-Tb, 1-Dy, and 1-Ho are 0.16 and 0.46 V; 0.16 and 0.45 V; and 0.11 and 0.41 V, respectively. Additionally, faster sweep rates resulted in broad features as a result of slow diffusion kinetics through the framework structure (b and S14). Finally, in all compounds, the postexperiment CVs showed no sign of dissolution or degradation of the frameworks upon electrochemical modulation (Figure S15).

elements.content: Solid–solution reactions of 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er with I2 results in oxidation of the TTFTB4– ligand to its radical zwitterionic state, [(TTF•+)­TB]4–. The solid-state diffuse reflectance spectra of 1-RE and 2-RE are shown in a and S17. For 1-Er, four bands were observed at 13 570, 19 420, 29 830, and 38 150 cm–1 (a). The small shoulder band at 13 570 cm–1 is likely attributed to the presence of TTF•+ in the framework as result of auto-oxidation, commonly encountered in TTF-based materials. Upon treatment of 1-Er with I2, the band at 13 570 cm–1 increases in intensity as a result of the oxidation of {TTF­(CO2)4} ligands in the framework. Additionally, a broader band that extends into the IR/NIR region centered at <5000 cm–1 is observed. The origin of this band is tentatively attributed to a (through-space) intervalence charge transfer (IVCT) band due to the presence of partially oxidized or mixed-valence TTF0/TTF•+ species within the 2-Er framework. The study of other lanthanoid analogues (1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, 2-Tb, 2-Dy, and 2-Ho) (Figure S16) showed similar features with the intensification of the band at ca. 13 500 cm–1 upon I2 exposure.

Additionally, a broader band that extends into the IR/NIR region centered at <5000 cm-1 is observed. The origin of this band is tentatively attributed to a (through-space) intervalence charge transfer (IVCT) band due to the presence of partially oxidized or mixed-valence TTF0/TTF⋅+ species within the 2-Er framework. The study of other lanthanoid analogues (1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, 2-Tb, 2-Dy, and 2-Ho) (Figure S16) showed similar features with the intensification of the band at ca. 13500 cm-1 upon I2 exposure.

elements.content: Prior to studying the conductivities of these materials, the solid state absorption spectra were obtained to gain insight into the influence of oxidation on the optical and conducting properties. In 1-RE, there are two main absorption bands located in the region 15 000–30 000 cm–1 ( and S16). The higher energy absorption band is attributed to the π* → n or π* → π transition of the free ligand, while the lower energy transition in the middle of the visible region may be assigned to ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT). After I2 oxidation, 2-RE shows an additional absorption band which is located at approximately 12 500 cm–1 and can be assigned to TTF•+. Thus, oxidation with I2 which converts neutral TTF moieties to their radical cations, TTF•+, largely improves the absorption of light by these materials.
elements.clean_text:
Semiconducting Properties

Prior to studying the conductivities of these materials, the solid state absorption spectra were obtained to gain insight into the influence of oxidation on the optical and conducting properties. In 1-RE, there are two main absorption bands located in the region 15000-30000 cm-1 ( and S16). The higher energy absorption band is attributed to the π* → n or π* → π transition of the free ligand, while the lower energy transition in the middle of the visible region may be assigned to ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT). After I2 oxidation, 2-RE shows an additional absorption band which is located at approximately 12500 cm-1 and can be assigned to TTF⋅+. Thus, oxidation with I2 which converts neutral TTF moieties to their radical cations, TTF⋅+, largely improves the absorption of light by these materials.

elements.content: Correspondingly, the optical band gap would be expected to decrease to a smaller value upon oxidation. Using the UV–vis-NIR adsorption data, we approximated the band gap of 1-RE and 2-RE through the Kubelka–Munk function. From the Tauc plots, the band gaps of 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, 1-Er, 2-Tb, 2-Dy, 2-Ho, and 2-Er are approximately 1.75, 1.75, 1.91, 1.85, 0.94, 1.21, 1.13, and 0.90 eV, respectively (Figures S17–20). In general, the band gaps for the oxidized compounds are reduced relative to their neutral counterparts, in line with the trends in the conductivities (vide infra). The band gap values, which are typical of semiconductors, are such that these materials could potentially be used in photo- and electrocatalysis reactions as well as in microelectronic devices.

The band gap values, which are typical of semiconductors, are such that these materials could potentially be used in photo- and electrocatalysis reactions as well as in microelectronic devices.

elements.content: Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of the solid compounds at 110 K are almost silent for 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er but are characterized by a strong resonance in each case at g ∼ 2 for iodine oxidized samples 2-Tb, 2-Dy, 2-Ho, and 2-Er due to the formation of TTF•+ (b and S21). These results further confirmed the generation of TTF•+ radical upon oxidation with iodine. A negligible weak signal around g ∼ 2 in the EPR spectra of pristine 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er indicates the presence of a very small amount of the TTF moiety in its radical cation form. The weak EPR signals for 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er could originate from the paramagnetic RE metals. All EPR spectra (which were recorded under the same conditions) exhibit g values of 2.002 (2-Tb), 2.003 (2-Dy), 2.004 (2-Ho), and 2.005 (2-Er), typical of the TTF•+ cation radical.
elements.clean_text:
EPR and Electrical Conductivity

Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of the solid compounds at 110 K are almost silent for 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er but are characterized by a strong resonance in each case at g ~ 2 for iodine oxidized samples 2-Tb, 2-Dy, 2-Ho, and 2-Er due to the formation of TTF⋅+ (b and S21). These results further confirmed the generation of TTF⋅+ radical upon oxidation with iodine. A negligible weak signal around g ~ 2 in the EPR spectra of pristine 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er indicates the presence of a very small amount of the TTF moiety in its radical cation form. The weak EPR signals for 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er could originate from the paramagnetic RE metals. All EPR spectra (which were recorded under the same conditions) exhibit g values of 2.002 (2-Tb), 2.003 (2-Dy), 2.004 (2-Ho), and 2.005 (2-Er), typical of the TTF⋅+ cation radical.

elements.content: To assess the electronic effects of redox modulation in these frameworks, conductivity studies were undertaken on pelletized samples of 1-RE and 2-RE. The room temperature electrical conductivities, 1 × 10–8, 7 × 10–9, 1 × 10–9, and 1 × 10–9 S·cm–1 for 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er, respectively, were marginally improved to 4 × 10–8, 1 × 10–8, 8 × 10–9, and 2 × 10–8 S·cm–1 for 2-Tb, 2-Dy, 2-Ho, and 2-Er, respectively, upon oxidation (Figures S22–25 and Table S3). However, the lack of band formation or the poor electron transfer results in low electrical conductivities. The slight change of conductivity for each framework can likely be attributed to the generation of defects during the TTF radical cation formation compared to the neutral counterparts.

However, the lack of band formation or the poor electron transfer results in low electrical conductivities. The slight change of conductivity for each framework can likely be attributed to the generation of defects during the TTF radical cation formation compared to the neutral counterparts.

elements.content: Magnetization measurements on fresh polycrystalline samples of 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er were performed in the temperature range 2–300 K under an applied magnetic field of 1 kOe. Their respective χM T values at 300 K of 23.23, 27.76, 28.29, and 23.19 cm3·K·mol–1 (a) are consistent with theoretical values for two independent LnIII ions, 23.64 cm3·K·mol–1 (TbIII, 7 F 6, J = 6, g = 3/2), 28.34 cm3·K·mol–1 (DyIII, 6 H 15/2, J = 15/2, g = 4/3), 28.14 cm3·K·mol–1 (HoIII, 5 I 8, J = 8, g = 5/4), and 22.95 cm3·K·mol–1 (ErIII, 4 I 15/2, J = 15/2, g = 6/5). As the temperature is lowered, χM T decreases in each case as expected from the depopulation of excited states and/or antiferromagnetic interaction. From a structural point of view one can define three exchange interactions (Figure S26) within one chain due to the three different bridging modes of the carboxylate. Given that the Gd­(III) ion is magnetically isotropic, the χM T of 1-Gd (Figures S27 and S28) decreases in the high temperature region due to the antiferromagnetic exchange interaction with J = −1 cm–1 (Ĥ EX = −2J 1 S Gd1 S Gd2) in dimers. In the low temperature region, the slight upturn might be from the ferromagnetic interaction and/or dipolar–dipolar interaction between dimers, or the ferromagnetic intrachain interaction. Also for 1-Dy and 1-Er, an upturn of the moment below ca. 6 K indicates one possible weak nearest neighbor ferromagnetic interaction and/or dipolar–dipolar interaction. At 1.8 K, the isothermal magnetizations (M) versus field (H) reach 10.61, 11.21, 10.59, 10.80 Nβ in 70 kOe for 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er, respectively (b). Magnetic anisotropy and/or the effects of low-lying excited states result in the low saturation values.

Magnetic Properties

Magnetization measurements on fresh polycrystalline samples of 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er were performed in the temperature range 2-300 K under an applied magnetic field of 1 kOe. Their respective χM T values at 300 K of 23.23, 27.76, 28.29, and 23.19 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 (a) are consistent with theoretical values for two independent LnIII ions, 23.64 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 (TbIII, 7 F 6, J = 6, g = 3/2), 28.34 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 (DyIII, 6 H 15/2, J = 15/2, g = 4/3), 28.14 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 (HoIII, 5 I 8, J = 8, g = 5/4), and 22.95 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 (ErIII, 4 I 15/2, J = 15/2, g = 6/5). As the temperature is lowered, χM T decreases in each case as expected from the depopulation of excited states and/or antiferromagnetic interaction. From a structural point of view one can define three exchange interactions (Figure S26) within one chain due to the three different bridging modes of the carboxylate. Given that the Gd(III) ion is magnetically isotropic, the χM T of 1-Gd (Figures S27 and S28) decreases in the high temperature region due to the antiferromagnetic exchange interaction with J = -1 cm-1 (Ĥ EX = -2J 1 S Gd1 S Gd2) in dimers. In the low temperature region, the slight upturn might be from the ferromagnetic interaction and/or dipolar-dipolar interaction between dimers, or the ferromagnetic intrachain interaction. Also for 1-Dy and 1-Er, an upturn of the moment below ca. 6 K indicates one possible weak nearest neighbor ferromagnetic interaction and/or dipolar-dipolar interaction. At 1.8 K, the isothermal magnetizations (M) versus field (H) reach 10.61, 11.21, 10.59, 10.80 Nβ in 70 kOe for 1-Tb, 1-Dy, 1-Ho, and 1-Er, respectively (b). Magnetic anisotropy and/or the effects of low-lying excited states result in the low saturation values.

elements.content: After partial oxidation with I2, the χM T values for 2-Tb, 2-Dy, 2-Ho and 2-Er at room temperature of 24.00, 28.48, 28.75, and 24.17 cm3·K·mol–1, respectively (Figure S29), are consistent with the sum of two uncoupled LnIII ions and one S = 1/2 TTF•+ radical (0.375 cm3·K·mol–1). The radical TTF component only contributes 1.5% of the total susceptibility. Similar temperature dependences to those of the as-synthesized compounds were observed. The moments for 2-Tb and 2-Ho decrease continuously as the temperature is lowered, but there is the above-mentioned upturn for 1-Dy and 1-Er below 6 K. At 1.8 K, the magnetizations (M) versus field (H) reach 10.26, 11.06, 11.12, 10.59 Nβ at 70 kOe for 2-Tb, 2-Dy, 2-Ho, and 2-Er, respectively (Figure S30).

elements.content: The temperature dependence of the ac susceptibilities (2 Oe) at different fixed frequencies (1–999 Hz) were measured for all of the compounds. Under zero dc field, 1-Dy exhibits both in-phase (χ′) and out-of-phase (χ″) ac susceptibilities (a and S31a), but no peaks were observed. The ac susceptibilities of 1-Er are similar to 1-Dy but 1-Tb and 1-Ho exhibit no χ″ in zero dc field (Figures S32–S34).

elements.content: The frequency-dependent out-of-phase (χ″) ac susceptibility below 6 K for 1-Dy reveals the slow relaxation of the magnetization. However, no peak of χ″ was observed even at 999 Hz, likely due to a lower anisotropic energy barrier (U). The χ′′ susceptibility increases with the increase of the frequency, suggesting that the peak maxima are to be found at lower temperatures or higher frequencies of the SQUID instrument. Even an increase in the dc field to 3 kOe showed no peak above 2 K in the ac susceptibilities of 1-Dy and 1-Er (Figures S35–S38). Assuming that there is only one characteristic relaxation process, the estimated value of U and the characteristic time (τ0) using ln­(χ″/χ′) = ln­(ωτ0) + U/k B T could be obtained. The calculated values of U = 3.6 K with τ0 = 7.9 × 10–6 s, and U = 3.6 K with τ0 = 4.4 × 10–6 s for 1-Dy and 1-Er, respectively. The magnitude of τ0 is agreement with the expected characteristic relaxation times of 10–6–10–11 s for SMMs. With low experimental energy barriers, no peaks above 1.8 K in the out-of-phase of ac susceptibility observed in 1.0–999 Hz frequency region were reasonable.

elements.content: In the case of 2-Tb and 2-Ho, no χ″ signals were found at zero dc field even up to 999 Hz (Figures S39 and S40). However, for 2-Dy and 2-Er, under 0 and 3 kOe dc field at the different frequency, the out of-phase (χ″) data at low temperature revealed similar slow relaxation of the magnetization (b and S41–45). The different χ″ signals between 1-Dy and 2-Dy can be owed to the exchange of guest molecules which could change the relaxation mechanisms. The calculated value of U = 2.2 K with τ0 = 5.3 × 10–6 s, and U = 5.2 K with τ0 = 4.7 × 10–6 s for 2-Dy and 2-Er, respectively. Thus, magnetic relaxation behaviors in the as-synthesized compounds (1-Dy and 1-Er) and their oxidized forms (2-Dy and 2-Er) are similar, while the partial oxidation of the organic to its radical TTF•+ form does not influence this effect. The reasons can be described as follows: (1) The radical TTF component only contributes 1.5% of the total susceptibility. (2) The TTFTB is not a conjugated ligand, and there is a torsion angle between the benzene ring and the TTF matrix. (3) The distance between the radical and RE metal is quite long which gives rise to a very weak interaction.

elements.content: Four MOFs have been realized from rare-earth metals (Tb, Dy, Ho and Er) by the use of a multitopic functional organic ligand consisting of an electroactive tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) center and four divergent benzoate linking moieties. These materials are isostructural with linear chains of the metal-carboxylate as secondary building units and the carboxylate adopting three different bridging modes, RE–(anti–anti OCO)–RE, RE–(syn–syn OCO)2–RE, and RE–(syn–syn OCO)4–RE. Nearly 48% of the solids are filled by removable solvents. They display chemical stability in a wide range of solvents, as well as thermal stabilities up to 400 °C. The TTF core was partially oxidized by a solid–solution method using I2, as evidenced by a strong radical signal in the EPR and the single crystal X-ray diffraction data. Only the Dy and Er MOFs display slow magnetic relaxation behavior which is not affected by the introduction of the radical by oxidation. We believe that these results shed light on multidimensional magnetic semiconductors or conductors in which the properties can be altered through redox modulation. Further studies focusing on redox-active conductive magnets and multifunctional magneto-electronic materials are in progress in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Four MOFs have been realized from rare-earth metals (Tb, Dy, Ho and Er) by the use of a multitopic functional organic ligand consisting of an electroactive tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) center and four divergent benzoate linking moieties. These materials are isostructural with linear chains of the metal-carboxylate as secondary building units and the carboxylate adopting three different bridging modes, RE-(anti-anti OCO)-RE, RE-(syn-syn OCO)2-RE, and RE-(syn-syn OCO)4-RE. Nearly 48% of the solids are filled by removable solvents. They display chemical stability in a wide range of solvents, as well as thermal stabilities up to 400 °C. The TTF core was partially oxidized by a solid-solution method using I2, as evidenced by a strong radical signal in the EPR and the single crystal X-ray diffraction data. Only the Dy and Er MOFs display slow magnetic relaxation behavior which is not affected by the introduction of the radical by oxidation. We believe that these results shed light on multidimensional magnetic semiconductors or conductors in which the properties can be altered through redox modulation. Further studies focusing on redox-active conductive magnets and multifunctional magneto-electronic materials are in progress in our laboratory.

Synthesis of [RE<sub>2</sub>(TTFTB)<sub>1.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]­(I<sub>3</sub>)·2­(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>) (<bold>2-RE</bold>)

A common method was used involving suspending crystals of 1-RE in a cyclohexane solution of iodine (0.1 M) at room temperature. The color of the crystals gradually deepens and after 2 days they were separated and washed with cyclohexane to remove excess and surface iodine. The amount of iodine incorporated was determined by single crystal XRD and confirmed by thermogravimetric (TGA) (Figure S12) and elemental analyses (EA).

<bold>2-Er</bold>

C63H54O18S6I3Er2 (M r = 2006.71 g/mol). Anal. Calcd C, 37.71; H, 2.71%. Found: C, 37.49; H, 2.78%. Selected FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 2921 w, 1659 s, 1605 s, 1584 s, 1537 s, 1419 vs, 1179 w, 1100 m, 1017 m, 857 m, 768 s, 704 m, 672 m, 568 w, 456 w.
